coredata.dc:title: Ground-state electronic and magnetic properties of MS2− 4 derived trinuclear M-Fe-S complexes (M = Mo, W)
coredata.dc:creator: Simopoulos, A.
Papaefthymiou, V.
Kostikas, A.
Petrouleas, V.
Coucouvanis, D.
Simhon, E.D.
Stremple, P.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Three trinuclear complex anions, [(FeCl2)2MS4]2− (M = Mo, W) and [(MoS4)2Fe]3−, were studied by Mössbauer and magnetic measurements. The results imply a high electron affinity of the MS2− 4 group and intramolecular spin coupling. These properties and structural features suggest these molecular groups as possible building blocks of the Fe-Mo co-factor of the nitrogen fixing enzyme nitrogenase.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 81, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 July 1981 GROUND-STATE ELECTRONIC AND MAGNETIC PROPERTIES OF MS4--DERIVED TRINUCLEAR M-Fe-S COMPLEXES (M = Mo, W) A. SIMOPOULOS, V. PAPAEFTHYMIOU, A. KOSTBKAS, V. PETROULEAS Nuclear Research Center Demokritos, Athens, Greece and D. COUCOUVANIS, E.D. SIMHON and P. STREMPLE Department of Chemistry. University of Iowa, Iowa City, Iowa. USA Received 24 March 1981; in final form 16 April 1981 Three trinudear complex anions, [(FeCl2)2MS4]2~ (M = Mo, W) and [(MoS4)2Fe]3-, were studied by Mossbauer and magnetic measurements. The results imply a high electron affinity of the MS^~ group and intramolecular spin coupling These properties and structural features suggest these molecular groups as possible building blocks of the Fe Mo co-factor of the nitrogen fixing enzyme nitrogenase. 1. Introduction In various nitrogen-fixing organisms the catalytic reduction of nitrogen to ammonia is carried out by molybdoenzymes generally referred to as nitrogenases [1]. Recent application of X-ray absorption spectro- scopy on the molybdenum-containing components of nitrogenase [2] have revealed the coordination environ- ment for the molybdenum ions to atomic resolution. The molybdenum K-edge X-ray absorption fine struc- ture (EXAFS) analyses of the Fe Mo protein of ni- trogenase and of the Fe Mo co-factor show three to four sulfur atoms at 2.35 A and one to two iron atoms at win A from the molybdenum. Two possible models proposed to be consistent with the EXAFS results are shown in figs. la and Ib [2] - Synthetic studies on Fe Mo S chemistry, guid- ed by the nitrogenase EXAFS results, not unexpected- ly, have intensified in the last three years. As a result several reports have appeared in the literature concern- ing the synthesis and characterization of Fe Mo S complexes [3 8]. In our studies we have obtained various Fe Mo S complexes employing the tetrathiomolybdate anion as a ligand for iron [3 7] - In this communication we -Fe r- ^1 \w^ y Mo ><x (o) Cb) \ /S ^\ / -^/^/\ f" s^ \ s' (d) Fig. 1. (a), (b) Proposed models for the Fe Mo co-factor after the EXAFS results, (c), (d) Trinudear Fe-M-S complexes (I) and (H). report on the magnetic properties and Mossbauer spec- tra of three of these complexes which are depicted in figs- Ic and Id. Interest in these complexes derives from their structural and electronic properties. Thus, the FeS^MoS^Fe core of the [(FeCl^)2MoS4]2- com- plex [5] could be considered a structural fragment of the nitrogenase Mo site (fig. Ib) while the magnetic and-EPR properties of the [(N^4)2 Fe] 3- complex 0 009-2614/81/0000-0000/S 02.50 North-Holland Publishing Company 261 15 July 1981 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS Volume 81, number 2 [6,7], indicative of an S = 3/2 ground state, resemble those of the Fe Mo protein component of nitrogenase [9] - The magnetic susceptibility and Mossbauer results reported herein reveal further features of the electronic structure of these complexes which may prove useful in comparative studies with appropriate features of the polynuelear site of the Fe Mo protein- 'oo- 85 1C-I, ~ W_\.. "VMi.kJ. mm irfl I ^^ ^ T-i.-'W'-?^"^- .sfW^ff ^ 2- Experimental Mossbauer spectra were obtained in the tempera- ture range 1.4 300 K. and in an external transverse magnetic field of 0.9 T. A conventional constant accel- eration spectrometer was used for the measurements. The source was 100 mCi ^(^(Rh) at room tempera- ture. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were perform- ed with a vibrating-sample magnetometer at tempera- tures between 2 and 300 K and in magnetic fields ranging up to 2 T. 3. Results and discussion Fig. 2a shows the Mossbauer spectrum of complex I at 4.2 K in zero applied magnetic field. The W homo- logue shows similarly a quadrupole doublet with slight- ly different spectral parameters- Values of the isomer shift and quadrupole splitting parameters derived from least-squares fits of these spectra are listed in table 1. The isomer shift values may be compared with other results on high-spin ferrous iron in tetrahedral coordi- nation, ranging from 0.86 mm/s for four chlorine ligands in FeCl^ [10] to between 0.6 and 0.7 mm/s for four sulfur ligands [11] - On the basis of these re- sults the isomer shift of complex I would be expected to be higher than the observed value. The lower value observed is consistent with a partial depopulation of the d orbitals and may be a demonstration of the un- usual delocalizing properties of the MoS^" ligand. We shall discuss further this point below in conjunction with the results for complex II. The quadrupole splitting is practically constant be- tween 4.2 and 300 K. for both Mo and W homologues, indicating that the Eg orbital states of a d6 conf%ura- tion, lying lowest in tetrahedral coordination, are split by more than 500 cm~1. This behaviour is a common oo ^y'-e^s: -6-A-20 2 4 UELSCITY (rBT/SEC? Fig. 2. Mossbauer spectra of the Mo complex (I) at 4.2 K. (a) and at 4-2 K and 0.9 T transverse magnetic field <b). (c) The spectrum of the W complex (I) at 4.2 K; and 0.9 T. feature in most of the complexes with a tetrahedral FeS^unit [Ill- Application of an external magnetic field of 0-9 T at 4.2 K has no effect on the spectrum of the Mo com- plex other than a small line broadening expected for a Table 1 Isomer shift and quadrupole splitting of (Fe2Cl4(MS4)I2~, [Fe(MoS4)]3~ and representative high-spin Fe(Il) tetrahedral complexes Compound 6 a) (mm s~1) Af-Qb) (nuns l) Ref- (Fe2d4(MoS4)]2- 0.57 1.98 this work [Fe2d4(WS4)12- 0.63 2.14 this work (Fe(MoS4)2l3- 0.42 1.04 this worfc [Fe(SPh)2MoS4]2" 0.44 1.96 [3] [Fe(SPh)4]2- 064 3.24 till IFeCL,]2- 0.86 2.61 [101 a) At 77 K relative to n-iion. b) At 77 K. 262 Volume 81, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 July 1981 diamagnetic complex (fig-2b). In contrast, the spec- trum of the W homologue shows significant magnetic hyperfine splitting (fig.2c). The diamagnetic behavi- our of the Mo complex suggests antiferromagnetic cou- pling between the S=2 iron ions, resulting in an S = 0 ground state. On the other hand, the magnetic split- ting observed in the W complex indicates that this cou- pling is weaker than that of the Mo complex. The antiferromagnetic coupling between the iron ions is further demonstrated by magnetic susceptibil- ity measurements- Fig-3 shows the temperature depen- dence of the effective moment p.^f and inverse molar magnetic susceptibility for both complexes. Deviations from a linear paramagnetic Curie behaviour are observ- ed at low temperatures- The temperature variation of the magnetic susceptibility was simulated by assuming that the electronic structure of the complexes in this temperature range is described by a spin hamiltonian of the form ^'=%l +%2- /sl s'2' where (1) %,- = D (4 - 2) + E(S^ - Sfy) (i = 1,2) (2) is the spin hamiltonian for the zero-field splitting of the individual Pe2"^ ions. The third term in (1) takes into account the antiferromagnetic interaction- The simulation depicted in fig. 3 by the solid lines was cal- culated with the following sets of parameters: J = - 11.5 K,D = - 8-5 K and E = 1.7 K for the Mo com- plex, andJ=-6K,D=-8.5Kand '= 0.9 K for the W complex. Although these sets of parameters should be considered as preliminary since there is con- siderable correlation between the values ofJ and D they indicate a substantial difference in the exchange coupling constants between the two homologues. The structures of the two complexes are very similar, but closer examination reveals small differences in Fe S bond lengths and Fe M distances (bridging Fe S bond lengths 2.295(6) and 2.319(6) A, Fe-M distances 2.775(6) and 2.802(7) A for the Mo and W complex respectively) which may be correlated with the differ- ence in antiferromagnetic coupling constants. c0 fe m 3. Fig. 3- Temperature variation of the effective moment ttoff (top) and inverse molar magnetic susceptibility (bottom) for the Mo (a) and W (b) homologues of the trinuclear complexes [(PeCl2)2MS4l2~. Solid lines are simulated variations including intramolecu- lar antiferromagnetic coupling (see text). 263 Volume 81, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 July 1981 The Mossbauer spectra of [Fe(MoS4)2]3~ (com- plex II) at 77 and 4.2 K in zero applied magnetic field are shown in figs. 4a and 4b respectively. In both cases the spectra consist of asymmetric quadrupole doublets but, significantly, the asymmetry at 4 2 K is inverted with regard to the 77 K spectrum. Isomer shift and quadrupole splitting parameters derived by least- squares fits with lorentzians of unequal intensity are tabulated in table 1. At 1.4 K the shape of the spec- trum is essentially the same as at 4.2 K. Upon applica- tion of a 0.9 T transverse magnetic field, a broad, un- resolved magnetic hyperfine pattern appears as shown in fig.4c. The temperature dependence of the Mossbauer line shapes described above has been observ- 99-' S S5f- o. Q; ^ ^ ^-^3^ ^t^wy-?" "S, r \ / f a \ /\ / V \ 1 - -^ ^yy. . ^ V [ ^ k'' A.' r'':b 1 i i [ - if V { [ V -2 0 2 100 a UJ 0- 99 -6-4-2 024 6 UELBCITY (m^SEC) Fig. 4. Mossbauer spectra of the [Fe(MoS4):;]3- complex at 77 (a), 4.2 (b) and 4.2 K and 0-9 T transverse magnetic field (C). ed previously in spectra of Fe3"1' complexes where the ground electronic state is split into a system of Kramers doublets with the | 1/2) doublet lying lowest [12,13]. The reversal in asymmetry and the complex hyperfine pattern arise from the effect of non-diagonal terms in the electronic hamiltonian [14] . The magnetic suscep- tibility measurements follow paramagnetic Curie-type behaviour above as 10 K with a magnetic moment per ion fiQ = 4.17 0.03. This value is close to the spin-on- ly value for an S = 3/2 system. Below 10 K the effec- tive magnetic moment decreases as a result of depopu- lation of the | 3/2> doublet. This implies an axial zero- field splitting parameter D of s5K. As already men- tioned, the assignment of spin 3/2 to this complex has also been made on the basis of EPR data [7]. A spin 3/2 ground state may be explained as arising from a formal Fe(I) valence corresponding to a d7 electronic configuration. To satisfy the overall charge of the com- plex the molybdenum should be formally Mo(VI) in this case. The other possible scheme is a Fe(III) S = 5/2 coupled antiferromagnetically to two Mo(V) S = 1/2. The latter scheme requires considerable charge delocalization from Fe to the MoS^~ ligands. Evidence for charge delocalization is provided by the value of the isomer shift. Although the correlation of valence state and isomer shift is complicated, it is firmly established that a decrease in the population of d-type orbitals results in a decrease in isomer shift [15]. Matrix isolation results for the Fe(I) d7 system give a value near 2.00 mm s~1 for the isomer shift [16]. A similar result has been obtained from alkali halides doped with ^Co [17]. The isomer shift of complex II is much lower than these values (table 1). A large de- crease in isomer shift has been observed in iron cya- nides and has been attributed to transfer of electrons from d orbitals of iron to low-lying IT* orbitals of the CN~ ion [18]. Subsequent ab initio calculations have substantiated this argument to a large extent [19] - In view of this, the isomer shift results reported here give additional support to previous arguments [6,20] that the MS^ (M = Mo, W) anions act as charge delocal- ising ligands by means of their low-lying vacant metal d orbitals. To discuss further the validity of this con- clusion, we have included in table 1 Mossbauer data for representative compounds of high-spin Fe(II) com- plexes in tetrahedral coordination. The value 5 = 0.64 mm s~1 for the complex ^(SPl^]2" can be consid- ered typical of sulfur ligands- This value is reduced to 264 Volume 81, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 July 1981 0.44 mm s~1 when one MoS^~ unit replaces two sulfur ligands [3]. On the other hand, the isomer shift for the tetrachloroferrate anion FeCl^", where Fe(II) is coor- dinated to four chlorides, is 0.86 mm s-1 [10]. Thus the isomer shift values for the Mo and W homologues of complex I can be explained qualitatively as the result of the differences in the individual contribution to the isomer shift of the Cl~ and MoS^~ or WS^~ ligands. Fi- nally, the electron delocalizing abilities of the MoS^~ ligands are evident in the IS value in this complex. Coordination of iron to two MoS^~ units leads to a stable species only in the form [Fe(MoS4)2]3~ which formally contains Fe(I) but with an isomer shift vdlue much lower than that expected for a d7 configuration. Clearly, the complex anions studied in this work do not satisfy the stoichiometric requirements as analogs for the active site of the Mo Fe protein of nitrogenase. Their electronic structure, however, as revealed by Mossbauer and magnetic susceptibility measurements, demonstrates two features that may be important for the active site as well: (a) the effec- tiveness of MoS^~ as a charge delocalizing ligand, and (b) the possibility of spin coupling in the Fe Mo S cluster through antiferromagnetic interactions. Thus the isomer shift values for the Mo and W homologues of complex I can be explained qualitatively as the result of the differences in the individual contribution to the isomer shift of the Cl~ and MoS^~ or WS^~ ligands. head.ce:title: Ground-state electronic and magnetic properties of MS2− 4 derived trinuclear M-Fe-S complexes (M = Mo, W)

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Nuclear Research Center Demokritos, Athens, Greece
Department of Chemistry, University of Iowa, Iowa City, Iowa, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Three trinuclear complex anions, [(FeCl2)2MS4]2− (M = Mo, W) and [(MoS4)2Fe]3−, were studied by Mössbauer and magnetic measurements. The results imply a high electron affinity of the MS2− 4 group and intramolecular spin coupling. These properties and structural features suggest these molecular groups as possible building blocks of the Fe-Mo co-factor of the nitrogen fixing enzyme nitrogenase.
